arguments.claim: No treaty between India/Pakistan for through traffic; no partnership/agency between railways

holdings.text: The notice under s. 77 of the Indian Railways Act fully satisfied the requirements and is valid; contention rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Before the learned Subordinate Judge it was conceded by the learned Counsel for the defendant that the notice, Ex. P-32, fully satisfied the requirements of s. 77 of the Indian Railways Act, and on that concession it was held that a valid notice under s. 77 of the said Act had been given by the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conceded by defendant before trial court; not questioned in High Court or special leave; mixed question of fact/law not reopenable at this stage.

holdings.text: s. 80 of the Indian Railways Act does not apply to through booked traffic involving Pakistan railway due to sovereignty and lex loci contractus.

anchor.surface_text: The statutory liability under s. 80 of the Indian Railways Act cannot be invoked, as that section applies only to a case of through booked traffic involving two or more Railway Administration in India whereas in the present case the Receiving Railway is situated in Pakistan and the Forwarding Railway in the Indian territory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.80 limited to Indian administrations; Pakistan independent sovereign; doctrine of lex loci contractus prevents extra-territorial application.

holdings.text: There is privity of contract between respondent and Forwarding Railway via authorized sub-bailment under s.72 Railways Act and ss.148,151,152 Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 72 of the Indian Railways Act says that the responsibility of a railway administration for the loss... If a bailee of a res sub-bails it by authority, then according to the intention of the parties, the third person may become the immediate bailee of the owner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Receiving Railway authorized to sub-bail to Forwarding Railway; facts imply consent; direct bailment relationship created; no treaty needed.

holdings.text: Receiving Railway authorized by consignor to sub-bail goods to Forwarding Railway, constituting direct bailment.

anchor.surface_text: Section 148 of the Indian Contract Act defines bailment thus A bailment is the delivery... If a bailee of a res sub-bails it by authority, then according to the intention of the parties, the third person may become the immediate bailee of the owner, or he may become a sub-bailee of the original bailee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Implied from conduct and necessities of through transit; no express document but facts irresistibly lead to conclusion.

holdings.text: Implied agency under s.194 Contract Act; Forwarding Railway is direct agent of consignor/principal.

anchor.surface_text: Section 194 of the Indian Contract Act says Where an agent, holding an express or implied authority... the respondent appointed the Receiving Railway as his agent to carry his goods... such person is not a sub agent, but an agent of the principal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exigencies of business imply authority to appoint substitute; direct privity created between principal and substitute agent.

holdings.text: Contract of bailment implied from conduct of parties between respondent and Forwarding Railway.

anchor.surface_text: a tacit agreement between the Receiving Railway and the Forwarding Railway to carry the respondents goods to their destination may be implied from the facts

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts and conduct sustain bailment; alternative to agency/sub-bailment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative basis; finder liable as bailee; applicable if no other privity.

holdings.text: Forwarding Railway liable as bailee under s.72 Railways Act and ss.151,152 Contract Act; failed to take care of ordinary prudent man; guilty of negligence.

anchor.surface_text: Section 72 of the Indian Railways Act says that the responsibility... the bailee is bound to take such care of the goods bailed to him as a man of ordinary prudence would under similar circumstances take of his own goods

holdings.reasoning_summary: Burden on defendant; no contemporaneous records; oral evidence insufficient; loss date not proved beyond limitation period.

holdings.text: Art.30 governs suit (loss of goods); Art.31 for non-delivery.

precedents.case_name: Bristol and Exeter Railway v Collins
precedents.cited_proposition: instructive and exhaustive discussion on the said three principles (agency of receiving railway to forwarding, partnership between railways, receiving railway as agent of consignor) in their application to varying situations

precedents.citation: Bristol. And Exeter Railway v. Collins 1

anchor.surface_text: Bristol. And Exeter Railway v. Collins 1 is rather instructive and it VII H.L.C. 194,212, visualises a situation which may be approximated to.

precedents.case_name: Bristol and Exeter Railway v Collins
precedents.cited_proposition: illustration given by Byles J. visualises a situation approximated to the present one regarding carrier entrusting goods to next carrier and liability ceasing
precedents.cited_holding: The carrier receiving the goods may [...] undertake to forward the goods by the next carriers, and on so doing our liability shall cease [...] we will receive it only as your agents for the purpose of ultimately paying the next carriers.

anchor.surface_text: De Buasche v. Alt 1 at p. 310 thus But the exigencies of business do from time to time render necessary the carrying out of the instructions of a principal by a person other than the agent originally instructed

precedents.cited_proposition: principle embodied in s.194 Indian Contract Act clearly stated: exigencies of business require agent to appoint substitute, constituting direct privity of contract between principal and substitute
precedents.cited_holding: But the exigencies of business do from time to time render necessary the carrying out of the instructions of a principal by a person other than the agent originally instructed for the purpose, and where that is the case, the reason of the thing requires that the rule should be relaxed, so as, on the one hand, to enable the agent to appoint what has been termed a sub-agent or substitute and, on the other hand, to constitute, in the interests and for the protection of the principal, a direct privity of contract between him and such substitute.

anchor.surface_text: in the result, the suit was decreed for a sum of Rs. 80,000 with proportionate costs. The appellant carried the matter on appeal to -the High Court of Punjab, which practically accepted all the findings arrived at by the learned Subordinate Judge and dismissed the appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed upholding decree for Rs. 80,000 with proportionate costs for non-delivery of goods due to railway's negligence
